data.title: Recent Publications Relating to Canada
data.text:
In lieu of an abstract, here is a brief excerpt of the content:

Recent Publications Relating to Canada PREPARED IN THE EDITORIAL DEPARTMENT OF UNIVERSITY OF TORONTO PRESS INCORPORATED BY MICHAEL D. STEVENSON This bibliography is intended to provide as complete coverage as possible of newly available material useful in the study ofany aspect ofCanadian history. In keeping with the diverse backgrounds and interests ofour readers, both scholarly and well-researched popular sources are regularly listed. It should be noted that items of a purely contemporary or speculative nature and lacking appreciable historical content are normally excluded. Furthermore, accessibility considerations logically dictate that materials cited have appeared in published form, theses traditionally being the sole exception . Suggestions for possible inclusion in Recent Publications are welcomed and should be forwarded with the necessary technical information to the compiler at the Canadian Historical Review offices. See also Canadiana, a monthly list ofCanadian publications prepared by the National Library, Ottawa; International Perspectives; journal ofthe Parliaments ofthe Commonwealth, issued quarterly by the General Council ofthe Commonwealth Parliamentary Association; and in the University ofToronto Quarterly, 'Letters in Canada,' published in the November issue. Regionally oriented bibliographies are included in each issue of Acadiensis, BC Studies, and Revue d'histoire de l'Amerique .franf(lise. MA and PHD theses listed were reported as recently completed in the Register ofPost-Graduate Dissertations in Progress in History and Related Subjects (CHA) for the current year. Users ofthis bibliography should bear in mind that all titles are listed only once. Because ofsubject overlap, alternative categories should be consulted. ABORIGINAL HISTORY BARMAN, JEAN. What a Difference a Border Makes: Aboriginal Racial Intermixture in the Pacific Northwest. journal ofthe West 38 (3) (1999): 14-20 BILHARZ, JOY A., and THOMAS s. ABLER. L'heritage de Kinzua: La reconquete du pouvoir chez !es femmes senecas. Recherches amerindiennes au Quebec 29 (2) (1999): 51-62 BLOCK, ALVINA. George Flett, Presbyterian Missionary to the Ojibwa at Okanase. Manitoba History 37 (1999): 28-38 CAMPBELL, ROBERT A. Bridging Sacred Canopies: Mi'kmaq Spirituality and Catholicism. Canadian journal ofNative Studies/La Revue canadienne des etudes autochtones 18 (2) (1998): 301-12 CARTER, SARAH. Aboriginal People and Colonizers ofWestern Canada to 1900. Toronto: University ofToronto Press 1999. Pp. 152. $45.00 cloth, $12.95 paper 326 The Canadian Historical Review CHUTE, JANET E. Frank G. Speclc's Contributions to the Understanding ofMi'kmaq Land Use, Leadership, and Land Management. Ethnohistory 46 (3) (1999): 481-540 COOK, CURTIS, and JUAN D. LINDAU, eds. Aboriginal Rights and Self-Government: The Canadian and Mexican Experience in North American Perspective. Montreal and Kingston: McGill-Queen's University Press 2000. Pp. 350. $60.00 DEER, A. BRIAN. La « loi des condoleances » et la structure de la Ligue Commentaire sur The Great Law and the Longhouse: A Political History ofthe Iroquois Confederacy de William N. Fenton. Recherches amirindiennes au Que'liec 29 (2) (1999): 63-76 DICKSON-GILMORE, E. JANE. 'This is my history, I know who I am': History, Factionalist Competition, and the Assumption of Imposition in the Kahnawake Mohawk Nation. Ethnohistory 46 (3) (1999): 429-50 HANNIBAL-PACI, CHRISTOPHER. Historical Represen,tations of Lake Sturgeon by Native and Non-Native Artists. Canadian journal ofNative Studies/La Revue canadienne des etudes autochtones 18 (2) (1998): 203-32 HUME, STEPHEN. Songs ofthe Nass Valley: Have the Nisga'a Overstated Their Borders on the New Map ofthe Nass? Canadian Geographic 120 (1) (2000): 58-70 JOHNSTON, LOUISE. Onontio, le grande arbre et la chaine d'alliance: Le discours du marquis de Beauharnois aux Kanehsata'kehr6:non, aout 1741. Recherches amirindiennes au Que'liec 29 (2) (1999): n-22 KEENER, CRAIG s. An Ethnohistorical Analysis oflroquois Assault Tactics Used against Fortified Settlements ofthe Northeast in the Seventeenth Century. Ethnohistory 46 (4) (1999): 777-808 KIMURA, TAKESHI. The Cayuga Chief Jacob E. Thomas: Walking a Narrow Path between Two Worlds. Canadian journal ofNative Studies/La Revue canadienne des etudes autochtones 18 (2) (1998): 313-34 KELM, MARY-ELLEN. British Columbia First Nations and the Influenza Pandemic of 1918-19. BC Studies 122 (1999): 23-48 LEGARE, ANDRE. An Assessment of Recent Political Development in Nunavut: The Challenges and Dilemmas of Inuit Self-Government.
